StudyObjective: To evaluate cognition performance in severe asymptomatic carotid artery stenosis patients undergoing carotid artery stenting (CAS) and explore the mechanisms underlying cognition changes using integrated MRI techniques including pASL MRI and resting-state fMRI (R-fMRI).

fMRITasks.TaskDescription: Participants underwent resting-state fMRI to assess brain activity and connectivity. The primary measure was the amplitude of low-frequency fluctuations (ALFF) and functional connectivity (FC) to the posterior cingulate cortex (PCC).
fMRITasks.DesignDetails: Resting-state design; no specific trials or blocks; participants were instructed to rest with eyes open; data collected continuously during resting state; response collection was based on brain activity measurements.

RestingStateMetadata.Instructions: Participants were instructed to rest with eyes open.

BehavioralTasks.TaskDescription: Participants completed the MMSE to assess global cognition, measuring various cognitive functions including attention, memory, and language.
BehavioralTasks.DesignDetails: Single administration; no specific trials or blocks; participants answered questions within a set time; responses were recorded as scores.

BehavioralTasks.TaskDescription: Participants completed the MoCA to evaluate global cognition, focusing on attention, memory, and executive functions.
BehavioralTasks.DesignDetails: Single administration; no specific trials or blocks; participants answered questions within a set time; responses were recorded as scores.

BehavioralTasks.TaskDescription: Participants translated numbers to symbols within 90 seconds, measuring processing speed and attention.
BehavioralTasks.DesignDetails: Single administration; participants had 90 seconds to complete the task; responses were recorded as correct translations.

BehavioralTasks.TaskDescription: Participants recalled words from a list, measuring verbal learning and memory ability across five trials.
BehavioralTasks.DesignDetails: Five trials of word recall; responses were recorded for immediate and delayed recall; total number of words recalled was measured.

BehavioralTasks.TaskDescription: Participants repeated orally presented lists of numbers in forward and backward order, assessing working memory.
BehavioralTasks.DesignDetails: Single administration; began with a two-number sequence, increasing by one number for each correct response; responses were recorded as correct spans.
